description.narrative: The overall objective of the programme is to bring about a transformational change in unleashing the growth potential of micro and small-scale enterprises by 2020.

activity-description.narrative: Growth potential Micro and Small scale Enterprise
Growth potential micro and small scale Enterprise
Growth potential micro and small scale Enterprise
Growth potential micro and small scale enterprise

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative: 1. 60,000 entrepreneurs trained 2. 18,000 entrepreneurs provided with business development services 3. 2,250 entrepreneurs provided with financial products and services 4. 12,380 new businesses established 5. 6,500 informal businesses formalized 6. 147,400 new jobs created 7. 18,000 existing enterprises expanded 8. 40% of programme beneficiaries are women 9. At least 60% of programme beneficiaries are youth -No. of strategic partnerships with stakeholders -Over 4 strategic meetings -No. of national Conferences (GEW) organized -No. of gov’t officials capacitated and sensitized -An autonomous EDC Established -No. of additional trainers and BDS providers -No. CoEEs capacity strengthened -No. of frontline officers trained -Guideline and action plans -No. of teachers capacitated -No. of students trained -No. of capacity building packages developed -No. of competitions conducted -No. of enterprises receive capacity building support -No. of innovative startups supported -No. of capacity building packages developed -No. of BDA trained -No. of self-employed people capacitated -No. of -enterprises accessed finance/Total loan released -No. of self-help groups established and supported -No. of MSMEs and self-employed promoting their product -No. MSMEs and self-employed access e-commerce vendors -Total no. of enterprises benefit from market access -No. of enterprises established -No. of existing businesses expanded -No. of new jobs created

comment.narrative: 1. 40,000 entrepreneurs trained 2. 8,000 entrepreneurs provided with business development services 3. 100 entrepreneurs access financial products and services 4. 3,836 new businesses established 5. 2,536 businesses formalized 6. 54,018 new jobs created through phase 1 of the programme 7. 2,500 existing businesses expanded 8. 30% of programme beneficiaries are women 9. 55% of programme beneficiaries are youth -38 strategic partnerships established with stakeholders -No. of meetings reports with partners -6 Global Entrepreneurship Week (GEW) hosted -4,631 gov’t officials capacitated and sensitized -Currently, EDC is not autonomous - 238 trainers and 587 potential BDS advisers’ knowledge and skills enhanced -16 CoEEs established/capacitated -4,631 officers capacitated -New target (=0) -Around 2,331 TVET/University instructors capacitated -New target (=0) -About 20 capacity building packages -4 competitions conducted -112,066 enterprises received capacity building support (trainings) -12 innovative startups supported -About 20 capacity building packages -2,331 BDAs capacitated -25,500 self -employed people capacitated -389 enterprises accessed finance/125.7 million ETB loan released -One self-help group established -About 3,500 MSMEs and self-employed promoted their product -New target (=0) -About 1,200 enterprises benefit from market access -12, 790 new businesses established -12,809 businesses expanded -141,927 new jobs created

-Establish 1 (new) EDC Coordination -120 employees of government and private institutions capacity developed -7 CoEEs in universities (5 existing and 2 new ones) Strengthened -Business plan competition - ~930 enterprises participated -A total of 1,880 entrepreneurs’ knowledge and skills enhanced -50 potential Trainers knowledge and skills enhanced. -Women account for 35% of total trainees Youth account for 60% of total trainees -A total 1,500 receive BDS through group BDS & 500 business skills enhanced through one to one -35% of women accessed BDS support -Incubation centers established - 13 startups incubated -Strengthen linkages with 10 financial institutions -A total of 1,000 people access loan -2,500 new enterprises established -4,000 existing businesses expanded -A total of 20,000 new jobs created

-The establishment of one coordination office is under progress -A total of 507 government employees including University lecturers and TVET instructors have participated in the capacity building training -EDC reached to a total of 50,092 entrepreneurs, indirectly, through the capacity building training to TVETs and University Instructors. - EDC, with its active partnership with the University of California-Merced, has finalized a business plan competition. A total of 933 SMEs competed for the competition. Prize money provided to five finalists of the competition.
-A total of 3,560 potential entrepreneurs and SMEs have participated in the Entrepreneurship trainings. -Trainers (ToT) conducted, and a total of 27 participants have completed the training, in which 22% of the participants were female. -Women comprised about 31% of the total trainees. -About 63% of the trainees were Youth -A total of 908 enterprises (both startups and existing businesses) participated in EDC’s group as well as one-to-one coaching and counseling -48% of the total BDS clients were women -A total of 10 startups identified for incubation purpose -Linkage strengthened with financial institution -73 businesses accessed loan from different sources – 19.2 million birr loan provided -1,044 new businesses established -1,996 businesses expanded -9,690 new jobs created

1.1 4, 140 entrepreneurs trained 1.2 Women account for 40% of total trainees 1.3 Youth account for 60% of total trainees 2. 1,400 enterprises provided with business development services 3. 35% of Women accessed business development services support 4. 150 entrepreneurs access financial products and services 5. 650 new businesses established 6. 350 informal businesses formalized 7. 240 existing enterprises expanded 8. 4,400 new jobs created

1.1 11,405 entrepreneurs trained 1.2 Women account for 7.3% % of total trainees 1.3 Youth account for 63.7% of total trainees 2. 1,147 enterprises provided with business development services 3. 35% of Women accessed business development services support 4. 61 entrepreneurs access financial products and services 5. 2029 new businesses established 6. 2213 informal businesses formalized 7. 1660 existing enterprises expanded 8. 4, 058 new jobs created

- Facilitate the implementation of the National Entrepreneurship Strategy (NES) -Conduct meetings with partners to establish coordination mechanisms for entrepreneurship development -Undertake research-based policy dialogue advocacies for improving ecosystem and delivery of services -Organize a national entrepreneurship conferences with a specific theme -Capacity building training to 160 higher government officials (30% female) -EDC expand its team with 80 more trainers, mentors and BDS providers -Provide support to establish or capacitate EDC’s incubatees -Upgrade existing CoEEs as fully operational incubator at Universities -Train frontline officers (60) who directly interact with MSME clients -Develop a guideline and action plans to mainstream entrepreneurship -Provide capacity building training to 320 teachers for entrepreneurial oriented curriculum development/teaching -Provided entrepreneurship training to 1,000 students (50% female) from higher educational systems and TVEs students -Provide capacity building training to 320 teachers for entrepreneurial oriented curriculum development/teaching -Provided entrepreneurship training to 1,000 students (50% female) from higher educational systems and TVEs students -Develop capacity building packages based on needs -Conduct competitions: i) National Business Plan competition, ii) Innovative Business idea Competition at Universities -1,080 Enterprises receive modularly designed capacity building packages -Provide support to 3 innovative start-ups through different incubators -Develop capacity building packages based on the need assessment -Provide training to 120 BDA for providing support in self-employment -Establish a credit guarantee fund with one of the MFIs/Banks -Support capacity building of two self-help group in credit and saving -Facilitate MSMEs for uploading their products on e-commerce -Facilitate access to market (240 enterprises) through establishing e-commerce service -Establish business to business network in different industry -1,500 new enterprises established -1,700 existing businesses expanded -A total of 9,000 new jobs created

The Entrepreneurship Strategy (NES) is being revised following establishment of Entrepreneurship Development StrategyVarious meetings conducted to promote entrepreneurship which created demand from government and non-government institution for EDI’s services This activity could not be conducted mainly due to budget limitation Capacity building training was provided to a total of 294 high and medium level government officials (28% female) Primarily, Public Entrepreneurship and Innovation training EDC has become autonomous, merging the Women Entrepreneurship Development Programme and the Entrepreneurship Development Programme A total of 60 more trainers and BDS Advisors capacitated through ToTs (27 trainers and 33 BDS advisors) Two CoEEs strengthened to become excellence centres for Entrepreneurship Capacity building training (including ToT in BDS) provided to 136 staff members of the MEGA project A procedure and guideline drafted, and also discussed with representatives from the MoE About 149 University lecturers and TVET instructors capacitated with entrepreneurship A total of 29,047 entrepreneurs indirectly reached to and benefited from the entrepreneurship capacity development program Various training packages developed and/or customized to the needs of different target groups Startup Incubation program conducted: A total of 372 potential startups (83 female) have applied, final six awarded prize (seed) money A total of 14,431 potential entrepreneurs and growth-oriented enterprises have received entrepreneurship trainings; women comprised about 25% of the total. A total of 5,983 enterprises (both startups and existing businesses) received EDC’s BDS support. Most of the trainings and BDS supports were conducted in partnership with and in cost-sharing schemes with different institutions 6 innovative start-ups supported Training and BDS packages customized to the needs of project participants (MEGA project) Capacity building training (including ToT in BDS) provided to 136 staff members of the MEGA project 22 sessions of CT (4-day training), and one ETW (a 6-day) conducted; 805 trainees attended the trainings Linkage established with two MFIs Busa Gonofa and Oromia Saving and Credit Association to facilitate loan to 160 youth participated in the USAID project One self-help group in credit and saving supported both financially and business development services Not conducted during the reporting period due to budget limitation Access to market was facilitated for selected clients through linkages and facilitating their attendance in the nationally organized Bazars and Exhibitions Business to business linkages facilitated through attendance in nationally organized Bazars A total of 5,210 new businesses established A total of 4,263 enterprises expanded their operation A total of 48,312 additional jobs were created
